results.title: Kangaroo Island
results.creator_credit: J.A. Correll and South Australian Government Tourist Bureau
results.brief_description: A day on the Island, starting with fish being landed at dawn from the Kingscote Jetty. Includes visits to the friendly seals at Seal Bay and the kangaroos and koalas at Flinders Chase, the Remarkable Rocks, lighthouses and beaches. Water-skiing at American River, swimming at Penneshaw and a poolside party in the evening.

results.title: Kama wosi: music in the Trobriand Islands
results.creator_credit: Les McLaren, Australian Film Commission and Nomad Films
results.brief_description: One of a trilogy, this films deals with the poetic and image content of the songs of the Trobriand people. With the use of narration and English subtitles, the traditional songs and dances, which comment on everyday situations of village life, garden magic, love, anecdotes, sea-faring, mourning and spiritual beliefs are explained. Instruments, native to the Trobriand Islanders, are highlighted. Narrated by Roger Hauofa.

results.title: Kama Sutra
results.creator_credit: Mira Nair, Lydia Dean Pilcher, Mirabai Films, NDF International, Pandora Filmproduktion and Pony Canyon
results.brief_description:
Centred on the text ‘The Kama Sutra’, this is in part a feminist film about class and politics in sixteenth century India but it is mostly a lush melodrama, featuring an exotic palette and explicit sexual posturing. Initially it is the story of two women: Maya, a rebellious servant girl and Tara her mistress and future queen who are childhood friends. After being publicly humiliated during Tara’s nuptial celebrations, a vengeful Maya seduces the king prior to his wedding night. When this indiscretion is revealed Maya is spurned and turned out into the street, despite the king’s burgeoning obsession for her. After falling for a sculptor of erotic deities, Maya trains to be a courtesan, eventually returning to the palace. Nair’s film operates as a critique of the class system and is a tract about self-determination and sexual politics, but it is overwhelmed by a simplistic script that supports predictable plot and character developments. Nair may have been reaching for a feminist interpretation of the erotic text as well as a narrative about spiritual awakening, but the pretension of the four main protagonists who embody stock Eastern archetypes, distracts from this agenda.

Producers, Mira Nair, Lydia Dean Pilcher ; director, Mira Nair ; writers, Helena Kriel, Mira Nair ; photography, Declan Quinn ; music, Mychael Danna ; editing, Kristina Boden.
Cast: Indira Varma, Sarita Choudhury, Ramon Tikaram, Naveen Andrews, Rekha, Arundhati Rao.

results.title: Kagero = Heat Wave Island (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
Oishi, a policeman, investigates the murder of Otoyo, a woman who was in love with him. In the course of his work he uncovers some secrets about her - a son abandoned on the island where she was born and several lovers, who were responsible for the death of her husband. A compelling mystery drama from the director of ‘Children of Hiroshima’ and ‘The Island’.

Credits: Director, Kaneto Shindo.
Cast: Nobuko Otowa, Misako Tomiyama, Mutsuhiro Toura, Kozo Yamamura.
